conclusion: Analyze the motion of the positively charged ball under the influence of both the electric field and gravity.
The electric field is horizontal, and the ball starts from point O with initial velocity v0 at an angle theta to the opposite direction of the electric field.
Electric force acts in the direction of the electric field, and gravitational force acts vertically downward.
The electric force can be resolved into horizontal component Fe_x = Fe and vertical component Fe_y = 0.
The gravitational force can be resolved into horizontal component Fg_x = 0 and vertical component Fg_y = mg.
The ball moves in a straight line at an angle theta to the opposite direction of the electric field, implying net force in the direction of motion is zero.
For the ball to move in a straight line, the vertical component of the electric force must balance the gravitational force, but Fe_y = 0, so the ball's motion is purely horizontal.
The electric potential energy change Delta U_e is related to the work done by the electric force: Delta U_e = -W_e.
The work done by the electric force is W_e = Fe * d * cos(theta), where d is the distance traveled in the direction of the electric field.
The ball reaches the highest point when its vertical velocity becomes zero. The initial vertical component of velocity is v0y = v0 * sin(theta).
Using kinematics, the time to reach the highest point is t = v0y / g = v0 * sin(theta) / g.
The horizontal distance d traveled in this time is d = v0x * t = v0 * cos(theta) * (v0 * sin(theta) / g) = (v0^2 * sin(theta) * cos(theta)) / g.
The electric force Fe is related to the electric field E and charge q: Fe = qE.
The work done by the electric force is W_e = qE * d = qE * (v0^2 * sin(theta) * cos(theta)) / g.
The change in electric potential energy is Delta U_e = -W_e = -qE * (v0^2 * sin(theta) * cos(theta)) / g.

The difference in electric potential energy of the small ball when it reaches the highest point compared to its electric potential energy at point O is Delta U_e = -qE * (v0^2 * sin(theta) * cos(theta)) / g.
